III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry
Description (1) An agency shall require a staff member who has ongoing
contact with children or parents to be a person who has the
ability, experience, education, and training to perform the
duties assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A foster care worker interfered with a DCWL and MDHHS
investigation.
Investigation Interviews:
On 8/18/25 DCWL Area Manager reported that during a joint
investigation with DCWL and MDHHS, Foster Care Worker
inappropriately shared investigation information. Foster Care
Worker reportedly contacted the Residential Director for the facility
under investigation (2025SIC0000938) and requested information
regarding the allegation. Foster Care Worker then called the
alleged perpetrator (Residential Staff) and discussed the
allegations. Residential Staff transferred the call back to
Residential Director, who then ended the questioning. In addition,
Foster Care Worker was aware of when DCWL and MDHHS
would be on site to interview the youth. Foster Care Worker
arrived on site and spoke to the youth about the allegations, prior
to DCWL and MDHHS. These contacts by Foster Care Worker
interfered with the DCWL and MDHHS ability to complete an
unannounced visit or interviews.
On 8/18/25 DCWL Consultant provided information via email,
regarding the allegation. DCWL Consultant provided a breakdown
of the communication that occurred on 8/13/25. DCWL Consultant
received the allegation at 1:14pm. MDHHS was emailed at
1:20pm to coordinate. At 1:22pm MDHHS emailed DCWL
Consultant and Foster Care Worker about coordinating to go to
the facility. At 1:22pm MDHHS Worker called DCWL and reported
that Foster Care Worker wanted to attend the interview with the
youth on 8/14/25. DCWL Worker stated that was not typical, but
she could be there with the understanding she would not be
involved in other interviews. The plan was for MDHHS and DCWL
Consultant to arrive at the facility at 11:00am on 8/14/25, with
Foster Care Worker arriving at 11:30am. Consultant spoke with
Residential Director at 1:44pm. Residential Director informed
Consultant that Foster Care Worker had contacted him repeatedly
2

about the allegation. On 8/14/25 MDHHS and DCWL Consultant
arrived at the facility at 11:00am to speak with Residential Director
and planned to interview some staff prior to Foster Care Worker
arriving at 11:30am to speak with the youth. Before 11:30am
MDHHS Worker got a call from Foster Care Worker, asking if they
were coming to the unit as she was already with the youth. When
DCWL Consultant arrived in the conference room at 11:30am
Foster Care Worker was already talking with the youth. MDHHS
began the interview process by explaining why they were there.
The child reported he already knew why. Foster Care Worker
stated she read the allegations to him and explained the interview.
MDHHS asked if Foster Care Worker read the allegations word for
word from the intake. Foster Care Worker answered, “Yes, was I
not supposed to do that”. After the interview DCWL Consultant
reported she and MDHHS Worker spoke with Foster Care Worker
about the importance of confidentiality and allowing the two
agencies to complete their investigation without interference.
Foster Care Worker was receptive to the feedback. Foster Care
Worker stated she had not worked with MDHHS before and was
unaware of how things worked. When DCWL Consultant asked
why Foster Care Worker called the alleged perpetrator about the
investigation, Foster Care Worker stated she did not know
Residential Staff was the alleged perpetrator, as they went by a
different name than what was listed in the intake.
On 8/21/25 Supervisor was contacted by email, but a return
message indicated they were out of the office until 8/26/25.
Supervisor was contacted again on 8/29/25. An interview via video
call occurred on 9/3/25. Supervisor reported she was part of the
email notification about the allegation regarding the residential
facility. Supervisor notified Foster Care Worker about the
allegation and let her know to contact MDHHS Worker to
coordinate. Supervisor stated she was in a meeting when the
allegation came in, so she was unable to talk with Foster Care
Worker as she made contacts. Supervisor became aware of
Foster Care Worker’s contacts with Residential Director and
Residential Staff after the fact. Supervisor stated she thought
Foster Care Worker was familiar with working with MDHHS and
DCWL due to her experience with the agency’s Independent
Living home. Supervisor reported she did not have any prior
concerns about Foster Care Worker. All staff complete training
about investigations and working with MDHHS when they
complete Child Welfare Training Institute training (CWTI) and also
through training at the agency. Supervisor stated she believed a
lesson was learned in this situation and Foster Care Worker will
take the correct steps in the future.
3

On 8/21/25 Foster Care Worker (FCW) was contacted by email
regarding the investigation. An interview was completed via video
call on 8/22/25. FCW reported she had been in her position with
the agency since 2021. Regarding the alleged incident, FCW
stated she received the MDHHS allegation via email from
Supervisor on 8/13/25. FCW was preparing to go on vacation and
wanted to make some contacts to ensure the youth was ok, prior
to leaving. FCW read the allegations and called the residential
facility to check on the youth and confirm he was physically safe.
FCW spoke with Residential Staff, not realizing at the time they
were the alleged perpetrator. Residential Staff reported the youth
was fine and did not need medical attention. FCW denied
discussing the allegations with Residential Staff. FCW reported
she spoke with Residential Director, who confirmed the youth was
not injured and did not need medical attention. FCW stated
Residential Director was not aware of the allegations at the time
she called. FCW stated she did not discuss the allegations by
phone. However, she had initially emailed Residential Director and
indicated she was reaching out because of the allegations.
Approximately an hour after FCW received the allegations,
MDHHS emailed FCW for information regarding the youth. FCW
provided responses to the questions. On 8/14/25 FCW went to the
facility to see the youth. FCW reported she scheduled the meeting
with MDHHS and DCWL Consultant. FCW confirmed she met with
the youth prior to MDHHS or DCWL Consultant arriving. FCW
asked the youth if he knew why they were talking with him. The
youth was unaware. FCW stated she did tell the youth the
allegations, as she was unaware she was not supposed to. FCW
stated the youth was confused about why FCW was there, so she
felt the need to explain. FCW explained the allegation and asked
the youth a few questions about if Residential Staff was in his
room or hurt him. The youth provided some details about the
incident. MDHHS and DCWL Consultant then interviewed the
youth without FCW participating.
FCW stated she had called in “a lot” of concerns to MDHHS in the
past and never had contact with a worker. FCW stated she was
truly unaware that she should not speak with anyone prior to the
investigation. FCW reported she has never completed training
regarding investigations or contact with MDHHS and DCWL. FCW
stated this experience has taught her about investigation
procedures and how to proceed in the future.
Email contact occurred with Residential Director on 8/20/25 and
8/22/25. In an email dated 8/22/25, Residential Director reported
4

that FCW contacted him by phone at 12:56pm on 8/13/25 and left
a message to contact her urgently. FCW then emailed at 1:10pm
and stated she had been notified of an incident involving MDHHS
due to staff hurting the youth. FCW requested additional
information and wanted to verify the youth’s wellbeing. FCW also
asked who made the report to MDHHS. FCW emailed again at
1:30pm and 1:50pm, asking for a phone call. During that time,
Residential Director spoke with DCWL Consultant and notified her
that FCW had contacted him regarding the allegation. FCW also
called the unit and spoke with the alleged perpetrator, Residential
Staff. The call was then transferred to Residential Director, where
he informed FCW that he already spoke with DCWL Consultant.
Residential Director informed FCW that DCWL or MDHHS would
be reaching out to her. FCW stated that she would be “coming out
to meet” MDHHS. Residential Director stated that his interaction
with FCW was above what is typically expected in similar
investigations. FCW had called and emailed multiple times and
spoke directly with Residential Staff, which was unusual.
Residential Director felt the investigation was not able to be
conducted with the typical professionalism and confidentiality that
would normally occur.
On 9/15/25 MDHHS Worker was interviewed via video call.
MDHHS Worker reported that after receiving the allegations, she
made notifications as required. She was then informed that FCW
had contacted Residential Director several times and reached out
to Residential Staff. However, it appeared the contact with
Residential Staff was not intentional, as FCW knew that person by
a name other than what was listed as the alleged perpetrator.
MDHHS Worker did not believe the allegations were shared with
Residential Staff by FCW. MDHHS Worker reported arriving at the
facility the following day, with DCWL Consultant, to find that FCW
had already read the allegations to the youth and discussed the
situation with him. MDHHS Worker was surprised as this goes
against MDHHS protocol for interviewing youth. MDHHS Worker
stated she never had agency staff do this before. After completing
the interview with the youth, MDHHS Worker and DCWL
Consultant spoke with FCW and explained how the interview
process should occur. They made it clear that MDHHS and DCWL
take the lead on investigations, and FCW cannot share allegations
or conduct interviews without coordinating with MDHHS and
DCWL. FCW was receptive to this feedback.
Documents reviewed
• Emails provided by DCWL Consultant, Residential Director,
and Foster Care Worker were reviewed. The emails were
5

consistent with the information provided during interviews
regarding FCW contacting staff and the youth.
• DCWL Special Investigation 2025SIC0000938 was still in
progress. A review of case contacts by DCWL Consultant
was completed. The Special Investigation contacts were
consistent with the information provided in interviews with
MDHHS, Residential Director, and Foster Care Worker.
• Human Resources file for Foster Care Worker held the
following relevant information:
o Hired 8/2/2021
o Training: BCS New Hire 8/18/21, Foster Care New
Hire 9/16/21, CWTI training 10/1/2021. Aside from
what is covered in CWTI and new hire training, there
did not appear to be any training regarding working
with MDHHS for investigations.
o Performance Coaching Form dated 11/9/22. FCW
was addressed regarding improper attire in court, at
the office, and in the Independent Living home. In
addition, FCW was addressed regarding their
communication/verbiage. Incidents quoted involved
FCW being defensive and accusatory with staff,
frequently mispronouncing one youth’s name, using
improper cultural terms for refugee clients, and
escalating a youth with improper language. Lastly,
FCW was addressed regarding the complaints the
agency received about the state of FCW’s office
space. Expectations were outlined and training
regarding “Professional in the Workplace” occurred.
o Performance Coaching Form dated 4/25/23. FCW
received a formal verbal morning after being
observed hugging and kissing youth on the head.
FCW reported it was “mom instinct” when the two
youth were going through something difficult. The
agency reviewed expectations with FCW and
completed training regarding “Therapeutic
Boundaries” and “Professionalism In the Workplace”.
o Performance Coaching Form dated 7/18/25. FCW
received the counseling due to FCW failing to
consistently meet essential functions of a
caseworker, despite support and coaching with
regular supervisory meetings. The agency reviewed
expectations with FCW and documented that
additional disciplinary action would occur if
expectations were not met.
Analysis A violation was found. Based on information obtained through
interviews and documentation, it was determined Foster Care
6

Worker made contact with facility staff and youth and informed
them of the allegations. Foster Care Worker reported she was
unaware that she was supposed to wait for MDHHS and DCWL
before discussing the investigation or conducting interviews.
Based on Foster Care Worker’s human resources file, it appears
the worker has not received investigation training aside from what
was covered in their initial training in 2021.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. A correcitve action plan is required.
